access.description: The registered URL returns a 200 OK directly — a HubSpot-hosted landing page with links to four product-specific documentation sub-pages. Two products (Juno EHR, RxTracker) link out to a dedicated schema documentation subdomain at ehiexports.junohealth.com with detailed native database table schemas. The other two products (ConnectEHR/CQMSolution, Patient Portal) link to HubSpot pages with procedural export instructions. The CTA buttons use HubSpot tracking redirects that embed the final destination in an x-amz-website-redirect-location header, which is slightly unusual but browsers handle it transparently. No anti-bot protections encountered; all content accessible via simple curl with a User-Agent header.

product_context.description: Juno Health (formerly DSS Inc.) develops healthcare software primarily for critical access and rural hospitals, behavioral health facilities, public health organizations, and state mental health agencies. Ranked #1 EHR for rural hospitals by Black Book Research in 2025. The product suite spans a full acute care EHR (Juno EHR) with clinical documentation, pharmacy, lab, imaging, scheduling, billing/RCM, surgery, nutrition, and care planning; a standalone pharmacy/medication tracking system (RxTracker); an interoperability/HIE module (ConnectEHR); a clinical quality measures tool (CQMSolution); and a patient portal. The table naming conventions (AU_PRESCRIPTION, AU_PHARMACY_PATIENT) strongly suggest VistA/CPRS heritage — 'AU' refers to automated pharmacy utilities from the VA's VistA system, consistent with DSS Inc.'s history of building commercial products on top of the VA's open-source EHR. Five separate products are certified, each with its own CHPL listing and export approach. Juno EHR is the core product storing the vast majority of patient data; the others are more specialized modules.
product_context.certified_module_name: Juno EHR (primary), plus Juno ConnectEHR, Juno CQMsolution, Juno Patient Portal, RxTracker

export_approach.description: Juno Health takes a multi-product, mixed-format approach to EHI export. The core product (Juno EHR) exports native database tables as CSV files — 1,256 documented tables reflecting the actual SQL Server schema. This is a gold-standard database-native export. RxTracker similarly exports 66 native database CSV tables. ConnectEHR exports C-CDA 2.1 XML documents (limited to USCDIv1 scope). CQMSolution exports QRDA I XML files (clinical quality data only). Patient Portal exports C-CDA formatted documents. The Juno EHR native export is the workhorse — it covers billing (RCM1500CLAIM, RCMUB04CLAIM), scheduling (SCHEDULE, SCHEDULESESSION), insurance (COVERAGE, ENCOUNTERINSURANCE), documents (DOCUMENTREFERENCE, FILESTORAGE, MEDIA), medications, labs, notes, care plans, and extensive lookup tables. The C-CDA exports from ConnectEHR and Patient Portal would only add clinical summary data already present in the Juno EHR native export. Non-tabular data (images, PDFs, XML, text documents) are exported alongside the CSVs to the host directory. The export is described as a 'manual one-time export' triggered per-patient or per-population.

documentation_quality.description: The Juno EHR documentation is excellent for the native database export: 1,256 individually documented tables, each with column names, SQL Server data types (INT, NVARCHAR, BIT, DATE, DATETIMEOFFSET, UNIQUEIDENTIFIER, etc.), ordinal positions, primary keys, and foreign key relationships to other tables. Table descriptions are provided but are often minimal (e.g., 'The primary key of the X table'). The foreign key documentation is particularly valuable — it shows how tables relate to each other (e.g., PATIENT references PATIENTDECEASED, LKMARITALSTATUS, LKRELIGION). The extensive LK* (lookup) tables document code sets and value domains. RxTracker has similar per-table documentation for its 66 tables. The ConnectEHR and Patient Portal pages provide only procedural instructions (how to run the export) with no schema detail — understandable since their exports are C-CDA/QRDA standards. No sample data is provided. No version numbers or last-updated dates are visible on the documentation itself.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: Juno EHR's native database export of 1,256 tables provides exceptionally comprehensive EHI coverage. This is one of the more thorough export schemas encountered — it covers clinical data, billing/RCM (including CMS-1500 and UB-04 claim forms with dollar amounts and line-item detail), insurance coverage, scheduling/appointments, documents/images, care plans, surgery records, nutrition requests, pharmacy (with VA-heritage AU_PRESCRIPTION tables), and imaging studies. The main gap is in secure messaging: while lookup tables for message categories, types, folders, and statuses exist (LKMESSAGECATEGORY, LKMESSAGEFOLDER, LKACTIVEMESSAGECONVERSATION, etc.), no actual message content tables appear in the export. This suggests the system has a messaging infrastructure whose content tables are not included. Audit trails are partially covered through ViewedBy tables (SENSITIVEPATIENTVIEWEDBY, DIAGNOSTICREPORTVIEWEDBY) and history tables (ENCOUNTERSTATUSHISTORY, PATIENTDEMOGRAPHICSHISTORY, SCHEDULEHISTORY), plus TRACE_XE_ACTION_MAP and TRACE_XE_EVENT_MAP (SQL Server Extended Events traces), though these appear to be more clinical workflow tracking than comprehensive access audit logs. The RxTracker export adds 66 pharmacy-specific tables. ConnectEHR (C-CDA) and Patient Portal (C-CDA) exports are limited to clinical summary data and add no data beyond what's already in the Juno EHR native export.

clinical.evidence: Comprehensive clinical coverage across 1,256+ tables: PATIENT (52 columns of demographics), ENCOUNTER (detailed with ADT history, assessments, billing, coverage, diagnoses, providers, precautions, and VA-specific fields), CONDITION (with body sites, categories, coding, evidence, stages), ALLERGY (with categories, reactions, manifestations), OBSERVATION (with components, interpretations, reference ranges), MEDICATION/MEDICATIONREQUEST/MEDICATIONADMINISTRATION (extensive medication administration tracking with barcode scanning), PROCEDURE (with body sites, complications, focal devices, performers), IMMUNIZATION (with forecasts, education, eligibility), DIAGNOSTICREPORT (with media, specimens, conclusions), CAREPLAN (with goals, interventions, tracking), NOTE (clinical notes with signatures, addenda, cosignatures), NUTRITIONREQUEST (oral diet, supplements, enteral formulas), SURGERYCASERECORD/SURGERYPROCEDURE, IMAGINGSTUDY (with series, instances, DICOM data), IMPLANTABLEDEVICE, and extensive VA-heritage pharmacy tables (AU_PRESCRIPTION, AU_PHARMACY_PATIENT, etc.).

secure_messages.evidence: Multiple messaging-related lookup tables exist — LKMESSAGECATEGORY, LKMESSAGETYPE, LKMESSAGEFOLDER, LKACTIVEMESSAGECONVERSATION, LKACTIVEMESSAGESTATUS, LKSENDMESSAGESTATUS, LKSENDMESSAGETEXTTYPE, LKRECEIVEMESSAGESTATUS, LKMESSAGEREPLYFORWARD, LKSMSMESSAGETYPE — indicating the system has a robust messaging infrastructure. However, no actual message content tables appear in the export. There are no tables containing message bodies, sender/recipient information for patient-provider communications, or conversation threads. The NURSEBRAINCLINICALCOMMUNICATION and DIAGNOSTICREPORTCLINICALCOMMUNICATION tables are clinician-to-clinician handoff communications, not patient-portal secure messages. The product has a Patient Portal (separately certified), which likely stores patient-provider messages, but this data does not appear in any of the export schemas.

billing_financial.evidence: Strong billing/financial coverage. RCM1500CLAIM (116 columns) contains complete CMS-1500 professional claim data including CHARGESTOTAL, AMOUNTPAID, ADJUSTMENTPAYMENTTOTAL, BALANCE, diagnosis codes (A-L), insurance details, provider information, and dates. RCM1500CLAIMSERVICE contains line-item service detail. RCMUB04CLAIM and RCMUB04CLAIMSERVICE cover institutional UB-04 claims. ENCOUNTERBILLING tracks billing per encounter with VALUEAMOUNT. ENCOUNTERESTIMATETRANSACTION and ENCOUNTERINSURANCETRANSACTION track financial transactions. BILLINGITEM and BILLINGITEMEXCEPTION track individual billing items. CHARGEITEMDEFINITION with PRICECOMPONENT tracks charge definitions and pricing. ORDERCLAIMRESPONSE tracks claim responses. MEDICALCODING/MEDICALCODINGDIAGNOSIS/MEDICALCODINGPROCEDURE track medical coding. ORDERABLECHARGECODE links orderables to charge codes. Extensive LK* tables for RCM statuses, claim generation types, billing types, payment methods, collection levels, etc.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Comprehensive insurance coverage. COVERAGE table with COVERAGEINSURANCEPLAN, COVERAGERESPONSIBLEPERSON, COVERAGERESPONSIBLEPERSONEMPLOYER. ACCOUNTCOVERAGE and ENCOUNTERCOVERAGE link coverage to accounts/encounters. ENCOUNTERINSURANCE and ENCOUNTERINSURANCEESTIMATE track per-encounter insurance details and estimates. ENCOUNTERVAELIGIBILITY and ENCOUNTERVAENROLLMENT track VA-specific eligibility. LKINSURANCECOMPANY, LKINSURANCEPLAN (with organization, payer identification, scheduling rules), LKINSURANCEPLANPAYERTYPE, LKINSURANCECLEARINGHOUSEVENDOR, LKINSURANCEINSTRUCTIONTEXT. LKAUTHORIZATIONSTATUS and LKINSURANCEAUTHORIZATIONSTATUS track authorization workflows. ORDERCOVERAGE links orders to coverage. LKCOVERAGEPLANVERIFICATIONSTATUS, LKCOVERAGERELATIONSHIPTYPE, LKCOVERAGETYPE, etc.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Extensive scheduling system. SCHEDULE table (42 columns) with datetime, duration, patient, encounter, location, status, check-in/seen/check-out times, transportation, body site, authorization status, and no-show tracking. SCHEDULESESSION with SCHEDULESESSIONDETAIL (including diagnosis, notes, transport equipment), SCHEDULESESSIONPRACTITIONER, SCHEDULESESSIONRESOURCE, SCHEDULESESSIONACTIVE, SCHEDULESESSIONCONFLICT, SCHEDULESESSIONCOMMENT. SCHEDULEHISTORY tracks scheduling changes. SCHEDULECALLLOG tracks call activity. PATIENTSCHEDULEPREFERENCE captures patient preferences. ADMISSIONWAITLIST with priority and status. Dozens of scheduling lookup tables for statuses, priorities, transportation, conflict types, blockouts, resource types, etc.

documents_images.evidence: DOCUMENTREFERENCE with CODE, FILESTORAGE, RELATESTO, and SECURITYLABEL sub-tables. FILESTORAGE table for actual file storage references. MEDIA with type, code, identifier, notes, reason codes, and part-of relationships. IMAGINGSTUDY with series, instances (DICOM SOP classes), endpoints, interpretations, and specimen references. QUESTIONNAIREITEMOBJECTIMAGE for questionnaire-embedded images. The landing page explicitly states: 'Some electronic health information might not be available in a table format; such as image files or pdf, xml and text documents. The actual files will be exported to the host directory along with the CSVs.' This confirms binary documents are included in the export.

audit_trails.evidence: Partial audit coverage through several mechanisms: SENSITIVEPATIENTVIEWEDBY (practitioner, patient, reason, viewed datetime — tracks who viewed sensitive patient records), DIAGNOSTICREPORTVIEWEDBY (practitioner, reviewed datetime). History/tracking tables: ENCOUNTERSTATUSHISTORY, ENCOUNTERADTHISTORY, PATIENTDEMOGRAPHICSHISTORY, ACCOUNTBILLINGSTATUSHISTORY, SCHEDULEHISTORY, GOALHISTORY, IMPLANTABLEDEVICEHISTORY, INTERVENTIONHISTORY, INTERVENTIONTRACKING, TASKTRACKING, MEDICATIONREQUESTEVENTHISTORY, PENDINGORDERTRANSHISTORY. TRACE_XE_ACTION_MAP and TRACE_XE_EVENT_MAP suggest SQL Server Extended Events trace data is included. PROVENANCE and PROVENANCEAGENT tables track data provenance. However, this is not a comprehensive access audit log — it's more clinical workflow tracking and change history. A full 'who accessed what record when' audit trail may not be fully represented.

issues: Secure message content tables appear to be missing from the export despite extensive messaging infrastructure (10+ messaging-related lookup tables exist but no actual message body/content tables are exported).

ConnectEHR and Patient Portal rely on C-CDA/QRDA export formats which inherently cannot represent billing, scheduling, messaging, or audit data — though the Juno EHR native export covers those categories.
ConnectEHR documentation explicitly states certification under 'limited ePHI USCDIv1 definition' — this suggests a narrower scope than full EHI for that particular product.
No downloadable archive (ZIP/PDF) of the complete documentation — the 1,256 individual table HTML pages would require scraping to capture fully, though the index page lists all tables.
Table descriptions are often minimal or circular (e.g., 'The primary key of the X table') rather than providing meaningful context about what the table stores.
No documentation version or last-updated date visible on any of the schema pages, making it difficult to assess currency.

downloaded_files.description: Main EHI export landing page with links to four product-specific documentation sub-pages
Juno EHR native database export schema index — 1,256 tables with alphabetical navigation and links to per-table column documentation
RxTracker native database export schema index — 66 pharmacy/medication tables
ConnectEHR (C-CDA 2.1) and CQMSolution (QRDA I) export procedural documentation — no schema detail, describes how to run exports
Patient Portal C-CDA export procedural documentation — describes how to run population-level exports
Sample table doc: PATIENT — 52 columns with demographics, birth sex, marital status, religion, veteran status, etc.
Sample table doc: ENCOUNTER — extensive encounter data with ADT, billing, coverage, diagnoses, providers
Sample table doc: RCM1500CLAIM — 116 columns with complete CMS-1500 professional claim data including charges, payments, diagnosis codes, insurance details
Sample table doc: SCHEDULE — 42 columns with appointment details, check-in/out times, transportation, no-show tracking
Sample table doc: COVERAGE — insurance coverage with plan, responsible person, employer references
Sample table doc: OBSERVATION — vitals, lab results, clinical observations with components and reference ranges
Sample table doc: MEDICATIONREQUEST — medication orders with categories, detected issues, dosage, event history
Sample table doc: DOCUMENTREFERENCE — stored document references with file storage, security labels, related documents
Sample table doc: NOTE — clinical notes with text content, signatures, addenda, cosignatures, questionnaire/encounter links

summary: Juno Health provides one of the more comprehensive EHI export implementations among mid-size EHR vendors. The core Juno EHR product exports 1,256 native database tables as CSV files with field-level SQL Server schema documentation, covering clinical data, billing/RCM (including complete CMS-1500 and UB-04 claims with dollar amounts), insurance coverage, appointments/scheduling, documents/images, and partial audit trails. The main gap is secure messaging — lookup tables for message types and folders exist but actual message content tables are absent from the export. Four additional products (RxTracker, ConnectEHR, CQMSolution, Patient Portal) have separate exports, with the latter three using limited C-CDA/QRDA formats that add little beyond the Juno EHR native export.
notes: The AU_* table prefix in Juno EHR tables (AU_PRESCRIPTION, AU_PHARMACY_PATIENT, etc.) strongly indicates VistA/CPRS heritage from the VA's open-source EHR system. This is consistent with Juno Health's origins as DSS Inc., a company that commercialized VistA for non-VA healthcare facilities. The table naming throughout the schema also shows FHIR-influenced naming conventions (OBSERVATION, CONDITION, MEDICATIONREQUEST, CAREPLAN) suggesting a modernized data model that maps to FHIR concepts while retaining the legacy pharmacy subsystem. The 1,322 combined table count (1,256 Juno EHR + 66 RxTracker) places this among the more detailed EHI export documentation sets encountered, comparable to large-scale vendors like Epic in terms of native database transparency.
